description: The Afghan parents of a baby born on a C-17 aircraft evacuating passengers to Germany named their daughter after the aircrafts call sign, a senior U.S. general said this week.

title: The Black Reporter Proved Right By History and a Fatal Tesla Crash: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

title: India hits a vaccination milestone, giving at least one shot to more than half of its eligible population.
description: India has given at least one Covid-19 vaccine shot to more than half of the eligible population, a milestone in a country that initially struggled to roll out enough doses for its 1.4 billion people.

title: The Bombings at the Kabul Airport
description: For days, many dreaded an attack on Hamid Karzai International Airport in Kabul, as Western forces scrambled to evacuate tens of thousands of people from Afghanistan. On Thursday, those fears were realized  amid the large crowds outside the airport, terrorists carried out two suicide bombings. The attacks killed at least 60 people, including 13 United States service members.

title: The Latest From Afghanistan
description: We have had smoke in the sky literally since the third week of July, Amy Ginder, a 47-year-old resident of Reno, said. We have been inhaling toxins for five weeks now. You cant be outside. You cant breathe. You cant see the sun.

title: Biden faces a tragedy he worked to avoid.
description: President Bidens decision to end Americas longest war was driven, he had said repeatedly, by his determination not to sacrifice even one more member of the military on behalf of an effort that he had long believed was no longer in the interests of the United States.

title: Jerome Powell speaks at the Feds closely watched annual conference.
description: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, spoke on Friday at an annual conference hosted by the Kansas City Fed, signaling that the central bank could begin to withdraw some support for the economy this year as the job market heals from the pandemic.

title: Chinas Celebrity Culture Is Raucous. The Authorities Want to Change That.
description: Chinas online censors have for years relentlessly silenced political dissidents, #MeToo activists, liberal intellectuals, satirists and anybody else who has threatened to disturb the digital peace.

title: Denmark says Covid is no longer a socially critical disease.
description: Denmark, whose health minister said on Thursday that the country had fully vaccinated 80 percent of residents over age 12, will no longer consider Covid-19 a socially critical disease. It will drop all Covid restrictions as of Sept. 10.

title: Together Bears Witness to Britains Lockdowns
description: LONDON  In Together, Sharon Horgan and James McAvoy play a couple in meltdown. And then the pandemic begins.

title: How Does My Garden Grow? With a Little Help from My Friends.
description: Two decades ago, just before my husbands favorite cousins Mal and Marge moved from the Westport, Conn. house where Mal had raised state-of-the-art rhododendrons, we were invited over to dig some up, in whatever size and quantity suited us.

title: Inflation rose again in July, the Feds preferred measure of prices shows.
description: Inflation in the United States rose sharply again in July, the Federal Reserves preferred measure of prices showed, a pandemic-related jump thats expected to fade but will keep pressure on policymakers until it does.

title: Apples Shrewd App Store Settlement
description: When Apple settled a lawsuit yesterday brought by a group of small app developers, it represented a shift in the balance of power in an app ecosystem that the tech giant has long tightly controlled. Just how much of a shift is up for debate.

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Robert Wright
description: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like todays episode with Robert Wright. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

title: Apps Try Putting Financial Literacy at Kids Fingertips
description: A new crop of mobile money apps are promoting themselves as part of the solution to a stubborn problem: a lack of financial savvy, particularly among young Americans.

title: Why Would an Economist Ever Look on the Bright Side?
description: Americas dismal scientists can paint even a blue-sky outlook gray.

title: How to Make Your Marriage More Financially Equal
description: A year and a half of pandemic living has revealed  or reminded us of  some persistent patterns around money, gender, marriage and families. And they arent always pretty.

title: How Do You Write Down a Scratching, Crunching Violin Chop?
description: Change is hard. All the more so for an old, set-in-its-ways instrument like the violin.

title: As Schools Reopen, Districts Are Desperate for Bus Drivers
description: As schools return to in-person learning with masks and social distancing, some districts are facing another challenge: getting students to class.

title: Pakistan emerges as a winner. What will it do now?
description: Just days after the Taliban took Kabul, their flag was flying high above a central mosque in Pakistans capital. It was an in-your-face gesture intended to spite the defeated Americans and a sign of the real victors in the 20-year Afghan war.

title: A Different Approach to Vaccinations
description: Delta Air Lines is charging unvaccinated workers more for health insurance. Heres what to know.

title: The Hedonistic Altruism of Plant-Based Meat
description: Ethan Brown contends there are several main benefits to consuming plant-based foods instead of animal meat. It leads to fewer greenhouse gas emissions, it consumes fewer natural resources and it is better for human health.

title: Emma Corrin Is Fine With Not Playing Diana to the Bitter End
description: Voting is underway for the 73rd Primetime Emmys, and this week were talking to several first-time Emmy nominees. The awards will be presented Sept. 19 on CBS.

title: Why Are Steve Martin, Selena Gomez and Martin Short Working Together? Its a Mystery.
description: Eliciting comedy from Steve Martin and Martin Short is usually a simple proposition: You just put the two of them together. Even as they looked back on their years of friendship and collaboration in a video interview earlier this summer, they couldnt help falling into a familiar rhythm of affectionately zinging and zetzing each other.

title: Powell Signals Federal Reserve Could Slow Bond Purchases This Year
description: Eighteen months into the pandemic, Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, has offered the strongest sign yet that the Fed is prepared to soon withdraw one leg of the support it has been providing to the economy as conditions strengthen.

title: The Guerrilla Street Artist Stumping for Larry Elder
description: Every now and again over the past couple of decades, the right-wing street artist Sabo has popped up, aggravating Los Angeles liberals.

title: When Your Wedding Day Is Sept. 11
description: One evening in March 2020, Angeline Disante, 29, was tasting teriyaki steak on a stick to be served at her wedding on April 15. Once the pandemic hit, Ms. Disante and her fianc rescheduled the wedding for Nov. 28. Not surprisingly, that one had to be postponed as well.

title: He Built a Robot to Prove a Point About Refugees
description: When Saidullah Karimi walks into the room, Athenas blue eyes light up. When Mr. Karimi straightens his arm, Athena does, too. When he makes a fist, then uncurls his fingers, Athena does the same.

title: Candyman | Anatomy of a Scene
description: Nia DaCosta narrates a haunting sequence from her film that uses shadow puppetry.

title: Messi, Mbapp and Running Out the Clock
description: Real Madrids first offer for Kylian Mbapp arrived, in writing, on Tuesday afternoon. It did not come as a shock to anyone at Paris St.-Germain, not really. Mbapp had only a year left on his contract. Negotiations over an extension had long ago hit an impasse. It was an open secret he had eyes only for Real Madrid. Clumsily, the Spanish club had made clear it reciprocated his affection.

title: How to Survive a Bear Attack
description: How much do you know about bear behavior and avoiding a bear attack? What you know  or dont know  could determine how likely you are to survive an encounter with a testy bear.

title: Watch a Scary Story Come to Life in Candyman
description: In Anatomy of a Scene, we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

title: New York Art Fairs Are Returning, Eyes Open and Fingers Crossed
description: Artworks are being flown in from overseas, the showroom has been spruced up and ticket sales have started for the Armory Show, which is readying to become the first major American art fair to come back amid the pandemic, when it opens Sept. 9 at its new location at the Javits Convention Center.

title: Rivian, Electric Truck Maker Backed by Amazon and Ford, Files for I.P.O.
description: Rivian, a promising and well-funded electric truck maker, plans to sell shares through an initial public offering, the company said Friday, just weeks before it expects to deliver its first electric pickups to customers.

title: Stream These Five International Films Now
description: In the age of streaming, the earth is flat  screen-size  with travel to faraway destinations only a monthly subscription and a click away. Weve journeyed through the world of options and chosen the best new international movies for you to watch.

title: Make a Cake This Weekend
description: Good morning. Its still Melissa here, taking over for Sam while hes on vacation.

title: Why Provincetowns Response to Its Covid Outbreak Was So Effective
description: A fourth surge of Covid-19 is filling hospitals around the United States, fueled by the relaxing of mitigation measures, the more transmissible Delta variant and lagging vaccination rates. In states and counties where Delta is surging, contact tracers are overwhelmed. But monitoring the spread of the virus remains vital to getting it under control. The public health response to a Covid-19 outbreak in Provincetown, Mass., in July offers an object lesson in how Delta changes the playing field and whats needed to manage the pandemics next phase.

title: How We Covered the Kabul Bombings
description: It was another big week of international news on The Daily  this one focused on the ongoing evacuation of American forces, citizens and allies from Kabul; American gun exports to Mexico; and the humanitarian crisis at the southern border.

title: Fossils Seized in Police Raid Demystify a Prehistoric Flying Reptile
description: Limestone slabs recovered in a 2013 police raid in Brazil have revealed the most complete fossil of a species of pterosaur ever found, providing new details about how the flying reptile might have looked and behaved some 110 million years ago.

title: Giant Puppet Ruffles Some Feathers on a Long Walk Through Greece
description: ATHENS  A giant puppet of a nine-year-old Syrian girl named Amal has been traveling across Turkey and Greece for much of the past month. It is the first leg of a 5,000-mile journey, one that is rich in symbolism as a new migration crisis looms in Europe following the Taliban takeover in Afghanistan.

title: William G. Clotworthy, Saturday Night Live Censor, Dies at 95
description: William G. Clotworthy, who as the in-house censor for Saturday Night Live from 1979 to 1991 decided whether Eddie Murphy could say bastard, whether Joe Piscopo could make fart jokes and whether inebriated Romans could vomit on network television, died on Aug. 19 in Salt Lake City. He was 95.

title: New Yorks Private Schools Tackle White Privilege. It Has Not Been Easy.

title: The Gentrification of Blue America
description: In my latest column, motivated by the California recall, I pointed out that the Golden States left turn on policy hasnt produced the economic collapse that conservatives predicted. On the contrary, the states economy has boomed, even as it keeps getting trash-talked by the business press: Between the election of Jerry Brown and the Covid-19 pandemic, both output and employment grew about as fast in California as they did in Texas.

title: Lila Gleitman, Who Showed How Children Learn Language, Dies at 91

title: 40 Million People Rely on the Colorado River. Its Drying Up Fast.
description: On a 110-degree day several years ago, surrounded by piles of sand and rock in the desert outside Las Vegas, I stepped into a yellow cage large enough to fit three standing adults and was lowered 600 feet through a black hole into the ground. There, at the bottom, amid pooling water and dripping rock, was an enormous machine driving a cone-shaped drill bit into the earth. The machine was carving a cavernous, three-mile tunnel beneath the bottom of the nations largest freshwater reservoir, Lake Mead.

His teams first home game of the season was just a couple of days away, and the Juventus coach had just been told that the player around whom his club had painstakingly constructed its modern identity was no longer available for selection.

title: Donald Newlove, 93, Dies; Novelist Explored the Depths of Drink

title: When the Book Review Went Really Harsh
description: From its very first issue in October 1896, the Book Review liked to deliver blunt edicts  and, as youll see, even blunter headlines. An 1898 review of George Bernard Shaws collected plays asserted that he has not a touch of the poetical in his composition, and the critic and satirist who is not a bit of a poet cannot reasonably hope to win wide renown as a dramatist. In 1907, Theodore Dreisers Sister Carrie was dismissed as a book one can very well get along without reading, and in 1908, L.M. Montgomerys Anne of Green Gables was panned because the main character greatly marred a story that had in it quaint and charming possibilities.

Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

title: Micki Grant: I Wanted to Open Eyes
description: Theater in Manhattan was bristling with Black voices in the early 1970s, but these tended to be heard in smaller spaces like the New Federal Theater, the Negro Ensemble Company and the Urban Arts Corps. Micki Grants Dont Bother Me, I Cant Cope spent time in such theaters before winding its way to Broadway in 1972, making it the first time a woman had written the book, music and lyrics to a Broadway musical.

title: How Candyman Star Yahya Abdul-Mateen II Became the Next Big Name

description: Im off next week  my wonderful colleague Margaux Laskey will be writing to you instead  and as I chose recipes for you below, I realized that this was my last newsletter of the summer, and that there are so many more recipes I wanted to share before its over. (Yes, summer technically ends in late September, but emotionally it ends on Labor Day.)

title: Music to Play NYT Games By
description: Games and music soothe the savage solver, so weve curated a playlist that you can listen to while you solve. All of the songs have something to do with our Crossword, Spelling Bee, Vertex, Tiles or Letter Boxed games, and we will be updating the list from time to time.

title: Ida is expected to gain strength as it churns toward Louisiana.

In his novels and stories, Maxwell frequently returned to small-town Illinois, and to, as Scott describes it, the particular civilization and culture and society that he knew growing up.

description: The largest published study to date of certain post-vaccine side effects found that people were at slightly higher than normal risk of blood clots after receiving an AstraZeneca or Pfizer-BioNTech shot. But the same clotting conditions were substantially more likely to occur  and over longer periods  among people infected with the coronavirus, the study found.

description: NEW ORLEANS  Helpless to improve her infant sons breathing as he was about to be intubated, Catherine Perrilloux did the only thing that came naturally to her in that moment, the worst of her life: She looked away and prayed. The boy, known as Junior, was two months old and gravely ill with Covid-19.

title: The White House projects that inflation and economic growth will rise this year.
description: The Biden administration on Friday said it expected economic growth and inflation to both reach their highest levels this year since the early 1980s, revising earlier forecasts to match the reality of the continued stimulus-fueled recovery from the recession.

title: Sticky Note Manifestoes Written During Quarantine

This week, were looking at elements of a video work by Cauleen Smith, the full version of which will premier online via Pittsburghs Carnegie Museum of Art (CMOA) on Sept. 3. (Aspects of the work will appear, too, in the museums lobby.) Smith also has solo shows at the Contemporary Arts Museum Houston and LACMA on view now.

description: AUSTIN  The Texas House of Representatives passed a sweeping election overhaul bill on Friday, clearing a major hurdle in a monthslong push by Republicans to introduce a host of new voting rules.

To many, younger peoples speech sounds messy and unconsidered, a kind of linguistic equivalent of bedhead. Twitter is full of perfectly normal people being recreationally nasty.

title: How to Enjoy Retirement Without Going Broke
description: Ive been asking readers to suggest ideas, and I got this one last week from Jerry Moskowitz of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.: I teach a class for seniors called Keeping Current in Economics and Finance. An interesting subject may be decumulation  how to successfully spend money in retirement.

But the bad news is that the petrochemical industry is counting on greatly increasing the production of plastics and toxic chemicals made from fossil fuels to profit from its reserves of oil and gas.

title: He was a baby on 9/11. Now hes one of the last casualties of Americas longest war.

Mr. McCollum had not been able to talk with his son, but the green dot next to Rylees name on a messaging app meant that he was online. That he was still OK.

description: The weather is warm, but the sun sets earlier, the surest sign that summer is nearly over. At my local market, the years last corn is piled high, and there are big baskets of shapely sweet peppers in every hue. It seems quite wonderful that stone fruits are still around  peaches, nectarines and plums.

title: What to Do This Weekend
description: This is a preview of the At Home and Away newsletter, which is now reserved for Times subscribers. Sign up to get it in your inbox twice a week.

Another said, the words auto-translated into English, Liberalism did not fail in Afghanistan because it was Afghanistan, it failed because it was not true. It failed America, Europe and the world see it.

title: My Neighbors Door Camera Faces My Apartment. Is That Legal?
description: Q: I live in a six-story rental building in Washington Heights, with five apartments per floor. My neighbor across the hall installed a Ring camera that captures the entire floor. It faces my apartment directly, providing a clear view inside whenever I open the door. Aside from the fact that its uncomfortable knowing that all my comings and goings are being recorded, I wonder if this is legal. What can I do about it?

title: Afghanistan Collapse and Strikes in Somalia Raise Snags for Drone Warfare Rules

title: Bob Diamond, the Tunnel King of Brooklyn, Dies at 61
description: Bob Diamond, an engineering-school dropout who discovered a long-forgotten rail tunnel beneath Downtown Brooklyn and later spent more than 20 years trying to revive the boroughs trolley system, only to be stymied by bureaucratic wrangling and his own eccentricities, died on Aug. 21 at his home in the boroughs Kensington section. He was 61.

title: Americas Founders Lived in a Foreign World
description: As regular readers know, I am a little (OK, more than a little) obsessed with the Early Republic period of American history and spend a lot of my time reading about the Revolution, the Articles of Confederation, the Philadelphia constitutional convention, and the Washington and Adams administrations. One of my takeaways from all of this reading is that for all of our modern-day worship of the founding fathers, we lack of a sense of how foreign their world was as compared to ours.

description: Nothing epitomizes the natural splendor of America quite like a national park. The designation evokes images of quiet groves of towering sequoias deep in the Sierra Nevadas, sweeping views of sun-drenched rock formations in the Southwest or waves crashing against granite cliffs in coastal Maine.

title: It Shouldnt Fall to Veterans to Clean Up Bidens Mess
description: The time was set. At noon Thursday, Marines would swoop in and usher a group of 29 Afghans through Abbey Gate into Kabul Airport for evacuation. With minutes to spare, Ahmad  the leader of the group  was still looking for N., an Afghan man hed never met. N. had tried, unsuccessfully, to enter through another gate earlier in the day, and he was now hoping to make it in with Ahmads group. The Marines would open the gate only once, but luckily they were running behind  potentially giving N. the extra minutes hed need to find Ahmad in the heaving crowd outside it. I was on the phone with Ahmad. A colleague in another country was texting with N., and we were trying to connect them. Time was running out at the airport gates.

title: The Week in Business: Delta Introduces a New Kind of Fee
description: On Monday, the Food and Drug Administration granted full approval to Pfizer-BioNTechs coronavirus vaccine for people 16 and older, kicking off a new wave of company vaccine mandates. Delta Air Lines announced a new approach to encouraging, rather than requiring, employees to take the vaccine: Starting Nov. 1, unvaccinated workers will have to pay an additional $200 per month to remain on the companys health care plan. Its unclear how effective the policy will be. Studies of employer wellness programs that promote healthy behavior, such as quitting smoking, by offering rewards or imposing penalties have shown little effect on employee health. But employees may respond differently to a program focused on vaccination, which doesnt require a long-term behavior change.

title: U.S. diplomats are unlikely to stay in Afghanistan after troops leave.

description: When Jake Millison went missing, his family said hed skipped town. But his friends knew him better than that, and they refused to let him simply disappear.

title: When The Culture War Comes for the Kids
description: Caught between a brutal meritocracy and a radical new progressivism, a parent tries to do right by his children while navigating New York Citys schools.

title: In a Busy Week for Hurricane Season, Kate Is Downgraded to a Tropical Depression
description: As residents along the Louisiana coast surveyed the damage left after Hurricane Ida came ashore, and a day after Tropical Storm Julian formed and was quickly downgraded, Tropical Storm Kate formed in the Atlantic Ocean on Monday, becoming the 11th named storm of a busy hurricane season.

title: Naomi Osaka and Andy Murray are among the players to watch on Monday.
description: Looking for some good matches on Monday, the first day of the U.S. Open? Naomi Osaka will open the defense of her womens title to lead off the night session, and Andy Murray, the 2012 U.S. Open champion, will play third-seeded Stefanos Tsitsipas in an afternoon match.

title: Unvaccinated U.S. visitors could soon face new restrictions on travel to Europe.
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union on Monday recommended that its member countries place new travel restrictions on unvaccinated visitors from the United States, a fresh blow to the continents ailing tourism sector and a sign that potential measures to curb the spread of the coronavirus might remain in place for months.

title: Band of Robbers Tie Hostages to Cars in Brazilian City
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Heavily-armed assailants stormed a small city in southeast Brazil early Monday, in a brazen operation to rob banks that included explosives, charred vehicles and hostages that were tied to the roof of cars.

title: Leslie Winers Music Was a Mystery in 1990. She Still Likes It That Way.
description: Leslie Winer seemed poised for stardom in 1990. The face of Valentino and Christian Dior the decade before  the first androgynous model, as Jean Paul Gaultier called her  had turned to music. Her first single, Skin, featured a club-ready backbeat and a hook about love and acceptance perfect for the United Colors of Benetton era. John Maybury, the director of Sinead OConnors Nothing Compares 2 U video, made the tracks clip. But Winers chiseled visage didnt appear in the abstract video, and Skin simply disappeared.

title: R. Kellys First Male Accuser Says the Singer Promised Fame for Sex
description: The racketeering trial of the R&B star R. Kelly resumed in Brooklyn on Monday with the testimony of two new accusers, including the first male accuser to take the stand against the singer.

title: This Rosh Hashana Salad Is a Fresh Take on Ancient Flavors
description: When planning meals for the fall Jewish holidays, I often think back to the food from Canaan.

title: Succession
description: Infestation. Insects. Ointment. This is not the stuff you might expect from  prestige TV that takes extreme wealth as its subject.

title: U.S. Investigating Civilian Casualties in Kabul Strike
description: Pentagon officials acknowledged the possibility of civilian casualties in Kabul, Afghanistan, following a U.S. military drone strike on a vehicle they said was carrying explosives related to an ISIS-K threat on the airport.

title: In Literary Organizations, Diversity Disputes Keep Coming
description: A rescinded award. Board members resigning in anger. And many public apologies.

title: The Earth's Deepest Secrets
description: Burrow far below the planets surface, and even there, humanity has left its imprint.

title: Aaliyahs One in a Million Finally Cracks the Billboard Top 10
description: Vinyl helped Olivia Rodrigo reclaim the No. 1 spot on the Billboard album chart this week, while a long-delayed arrival on streaming brought a 25-year-old album by Aaliyah to the Top 10 for the first time.

title: Review: Martin Short Kills in Only Murders in the Building
description: Martin Short gives a master class in Only Murders in the Building, the 10-episode Hulu series in which he stars with Selena Gomez and Steve Martin. (The first three episodes premiere Tuesday.) Its not a class in acting or comedy so much as it is a seminar in agelessness and professionalism, and in Shorts unmatched ability to turn self-absorption into a virtue.

title: Jake Pauls Big Night: 16,000 Fans, a Tweet From LeBron and a Win
description: In the fifth round of their boxing match on Sunday, after Jake Paul nearly landed a clean blow to Tyron Woodleys face, Paul sneered at his opponent and then playfully pretended to lick his gloves. The orange mitts were coordinated with his orange trunks, which were equipped with an electronic screen that projected his name near his waist.

title: As the Afghanistan Deadline Arrives
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.S. Education Department is investigating five states over their mask mandate bans.
description: WASHINGTON  The Education Department has initiated investigations into five states whose prohibitions on universal mask mandates in schools may run afoul of civil rights laws protecting students with disabilities, federal officials announced Monday.

title: Lorde Steals Her Sunshine Back
description: Lordes new album Solar Power marks a pivot for the New Zealand singer-songwriter, away from the insular and intimate relationship tension captured on her last album, Melodrama from 2017, into a brighter palette and songs about embracing wellness and posi vibes.

title: Supreme Court Asked to Block Texas Law Banning Most Abortions
description: WASHINGTON  Abortion providers in Texas asked the Supreme Court on Monday to block a state law banning abortions in the state as early as six weeks into pregnancy. The law, one of the most restrictive in the nation, is poised to go into effect on Wednesday.

title: Starbucks Faces Rare Union Challenge as Buffalo Workers Seek Vote
description: For years, Starbucks workers have complained about the companys labor practices, saying that chronic understaffing has led to a chaotic work environment, erratic hours and difficulty taking sick days.

title: N.J. will end pandemic unemployment benefits this weekend.
description: New Jersey will end special unemployment benefits put in place during the pandemic when they expire on Saturday, rather than using federal relief funds to extend them, the states governor announced on Monday.

title: Human Most of All: In Moscow, a Theater Stages Gorbachev
description: MOSCOW  In August 1991, Mikhail Gorbachev, the last leader of the Soviet Union, returned to Moscow with his family from house arrest in Crimea after a K.G.B.-managed anti-democracy coup had failed to depose him.

title: New data confirm Covid vaccines provide strong protection against hospitalization.
description: New data presented to a Centers for Disease Control and Prevention committee provided more evidence that the Covid-19 vaccines provided robust protection against severe disease through July, after the Delta variant of the coronavirus had spread widely through the United States.

title: When the Silent Majority Isnt White
description: In her 1990 book Fear of Falling, Barbara Ehrenreich detailed how the widely broadcast violence at the 1968 Democratic National Convention in Chicago led to an immediate, dramatic paradigm shift in media coverage. In the month before the event, Mayor Richard Daley had denounced the various anti-Vietnam War protest groups who were planning to converge outside the citys International Amphitheater. When those protesters arrived, Daley fought back with his police force who, on Aug. 28, attacked protesters in Grant Park.

title: Whats Better, a Prize or a Patent?
description: Earlier this year, Elon Musk, the billionaire co-founder and chief executive of Tesla, promised $100 million in prizes to inventors who come up with ways to remove greenhouse gases from the atmosphere. The rewards, which will be awarded by the X Prize Foundation, are part of a cornucopia of cash thats being dangled to induce innovation around the world. The European Innovation Council, the MacArthur Foundation, and the U.S. government through the America Competes Reauthorization Act of 2010 are among those splashing around big bucks.

title: What Voters in a California Swing District Say About Afghanistan
description: HACIENDA HEIGHTS, Calif.  Brenda and Leo Ortiz had paid enough attention to the news from Afghanistan that it was hardly a surprise when their 11-year-old son asked them a question: How could so many Americans be killed last week?

title: E.U. Proposes New Travel Restrictions on Unvaccinated U.S. Visitors
description: BRUSSELS  Back in June, the European Union urged its member countries to reopen their borders to travelers from the United States, hoping to give a boost to the continents ailing tourism sector in the crucial summer season.

title: New Yorks Brief Hot Restaurant Summer: Bread Binges and Dance Parties
description: As the Covid-19 vaccines rolled out in the spring, many New Yorkers anticipated a summer filled with rampant pleasure and maskless debauchery. The overwhelming energy was: Were off the hook, and its time to party.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: The last U.S. troops have left the airport in Kabul, signifying the end of a two-decade fight and the beginning of a Taliban-controlled chapter for the country, U.S. military officials said.

title: White House Weighs Clemency to Keep Some Drug Offenders Confined at Home
description: WASHINGTON  President Biden is considering using his clemency powers to commute the sentences of certain federal drug offenders released to home confinement during the pandemic rather than forcing them to return to prison after the pandemic emergency ends, according to officials familiar with internal deliberations.

title: Howie Rose Steps Away From Mets, but Plans to Return Next Year
description: Howie Rose, the longtime Mets radio and television play-by-play broadcaster, announced on Monday that he will miss the final month of the regular season to have surgery for an undisclosed medical issue. Rose said he will have the operation on Friday and will announce his last game of the season either Tuesday or Wednesday, depending on the weather.

title: Will Robots Change Human Relationships?
description: For better and for worse, robots will alter humans capacity for altruism, love, and friendship.

title: Music for the Migrant Crisis
description: How Italy fell for Ghali.

title: Oysters, in the Form of a C.S.A.
description: Faced with the pandemic putting an end to his New York bartending job, Aaron Waldman returned to Maine, his home state, and a year or so ago started the Worlds Your Oyster Company, distributing cultivated oysters from Maine and Eastern Canada to restaurants. Earlier this year he expanded his market, offering oysters to consumers on a C.S.A. basis, with weekly or biweekly deliveries to locations in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and the Hudson Valley. Other shellfish like clams can be included. Memberships in the September-October C.S.A. are now open and feature oyster farms owned or managed by women.

title: Get Off My Lawn
description: How a small group of activists (a correspondent from The Atlantic among them) got leaf blowers banned in the nations capital.

title: A Sip of Paradise
description: St. Agrestis, the Brooklyn distiller known for its Italian approach to amaro and cocktails like the Negroni, has introduced a new aperitivo. Called Paradiso and sold in a distinctive tapered bottle like St. Agrestiss other products, its the mellow yang to the decidedly bitter yin of the companys Inferno Bitter and is formulated to be the foundation of a spritz. The honey-colored 40-proof spirit is made with a wine base, gets its bracing profile from blood orange and citrus peels, and has a spicy aroma with a hint of baked apple on the palate. Come fall, blend it in a spritz with sparkling hard cider (try Brooklyn Cider House Bone Dry) or simply enjoy it on the rocks.

title: A Chefs Apron From Tom Colicchio
description: The chef and restaurateur Tom Colicchio has collaborated on the design of an efficient new apron from Tilit, a company that makes chefs garb. In blue or green, its made from organic duck cotton with waxed cotton; a white one is all duck. All have a leather strap and a front zip pocket. They are $115, with $10 of the price being donated to Edible Schoolyard NYC.

title: A Streusel Cake to Write Home About
description: The new streusel cakes from the Vienna Cookie Company in Baldwin, N.Y., are defined by their fillings of fruit, chocolate or nuts, sandwiched in between a tender cookielike base and a rich crumb topping. The cakes are the owner Heidi Rieglers refinement of the typical New York coffee shop crumb cake and can go from breakfast to dessert. They will easily accept a pouf of yogurt, whipped cream or ice cream. Ms. Riegler uses local farmers market peaches and blueberries in her fillings, combines chocolate chips and ganache for the chocolate flavor, and soaks pecans in Grand Marnier for another variety.

title: The Lighter Side of Octopus
description: Justin Smillie, the executive chef for the Il Buco restaurants in Manhattan and in Amagansett, N.Y., wanted to devise a lighter take on octopus. I was looking for something other than the big steaky chunks you always see, he said. So instead of cutting meaty cross-sections of the tentacles, he shaved them into ribbons the long way, quickly seared the strips on a plancha and tossed them with tiny tomatoes, herbs, a bit of Fresno chile and olive oil for his delectable, crispy octopus dish ($26, among the small plates at Il Buco Al Mare). He starts with cooked octopus and uses a meat slicer; for home cooks, a sharp knife works. He recommends marinating the strips before cooking, and also suggests threading them on skewers or tossing them with pasta or into rice dishes.

title: The Blush of Pineapple, From a New Online Source
description: Yes, they sell fragrant, juicy lychees, rambutans, mangosteens, dragon fruit, soursop and more. But the jewel in the crown from Full Moon Fruits, a fledgling fruit company, is the pink pineapple. With flesh the color of ros, this rare pineapple from Costa Rica is irresistibly sweeter and less acidic than the yellow variety, delivering an almost cotton candy flavor. Uncut, theyre not so Instagrammable, sold without a crown of leaves because the tops are used to propagate subsequent crops. Matt Dembo, a marketing executive and a founder of the company, said he got into the fruit game as a sideline four years ago after sampling some of the fruits he found in stores in the Los Angeles area where he is based. He started sending various fruits, including some rare varieties, to friends, and before long was in business. He said he buys from small growers in California and in countries in Central America and elsewhere, preferably those who avoid chemicals. Prices start at about $5 for individual fruits by the pound; assortments are $39.99 and up.

title: Louisiana is grappling with oxygen shortages in Idas aftermath.
description: Oxygen supplies are running critically low in hospitals across Louisiana  with some only having one or two days of supply left  and any interruption brought by Hurricane Idas destruction could be serious, according to Premier Inc., one of the largest hospital supply purchasing groups in the country.

title: How Alcohol Affects the Heart
description: A new study has found that consuming alcohol, even as little as one can of beer or one glass of wine, can quickly increase the risk of a common type of cardiac arrhythmia known as atrial fibrillation in people who have a history of the condition.

title: Ida Hit One of the Countrys Biggest Oil and Chemical Hubs
description: The most intense hurricane on record to strike Louisiana swept through one of the nations largest chemical, petroleum and natural gas hubs. And while it may take days or weeks for the full extent of the storms impact to become clear, early reports of damage have heightened concerns over the vulnerability of the regions fossil fuel infrastructure to intensifying storms.

title: Lights Flickered in New York City. Why Did the Subways Grind to a Halt?
description: For most New Yorkers, it was a blink-or-you-miss-it event. Lights flickered across the city on Sunday night. Some clocks reset.

title: Hurricane Ida Exposes Grid Weaknesses as New Orleans Goes Dark
description: Most of New Orleans went dark on Sunday after Hurricane Ida took out transmission lines and forced power plants offline. It was an all too familiar scene in a city that has often lost power during big storms.

title: Evacuations Ordered Near Lake Tahoe as the Caldor Fire Chokes Region
description: A wildfire that had burned through remote areas in the Sierra Nevada for two weeks crested a ridge on Monday and began descending toward the major population centers along Lake Tahoe.

title: The Fertility Doctor's Secret
description: Donald Cline must have thought no one would ever know. Then DNA testing came along.

title: The S.E.C. head is considering banning a key way Robinhood makes money.
description: Gary Gensler, the chair of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said on Monday that a ban was on the table for a practice that underpins some of the most popular free stock-trading apps.

title: Wide Awake at 3 A.M.? Our Readers Offer Advice.
description: Most sleep experts offer standard advice to people who occasionally wake up at 3 a.m. and cant fall back to sleep after 20 minutes or so: Ignore the clock, get out of bed and do a calming activity. Then, return to bed when you start to feel sleepy again.

title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Hurricane Ida made landfall southwest of New Orleans on Sunday as a Category 4 hurricane before moving into Mississippi, walloping hospitals in two states that were already brimming with Covid patients.

title: The Most Honest Book About Climate Change Yet
description: William T. Vollmanns latest opus is brilliant, but it offers no comfort to its readers.

title: Afghan Family Says Errant U.S. Missile Killed 10, Including 7 Children
description: KABUL  Zemari Ahmadi was coming home Sunday evening, having dropped off colleagues from the local office of an American aid group where he worked, relatives and colleagues said in interviews Monday.

title: A Radical New Scheme to Prevent Catastrophic Sea-Level Rise
description: A Princeton glaciologist says a set of mega-engineering projects may be able to stabilize the worlds most dangerous glaciers.

title: When Will Climate Change Make the Earth Too Hot for Humans?
description: Famine, economic collapse, a sun that cooks us: What climate change could wreak  sooner than you think.

title: Watch One of the Best Current Comedies on TV
description: This is a preview of the Watching newsletter, which is now reserved for Times subscribers. Sign up to get it in your inbox four times a week.

title: Kenny Malone, Premier Drummer for Top Nashville Names, Dies at 83
description: NASHVILLE  Kenny Malone, a prolific Nashville session drummer whose skittering snare rhythms haunted Dolly Partons No. 1 country hit Jolene in 1973 and whose swinging jazz groove anchored Crystal Gayles crossover smash Dont It Make My Brown Eyes Blue in 1977, died at a hospital here on Thursday. He was 83.

title: Afghanistan, Ida, Mask Mandates: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Jacques Rogge, Who Led Olympic Committee, Dies at 79
description: Jacques Rogge, who became president of the International Olympic Committee in 2001, when the organization was still reeling from an ethics scandal, and helped restore stability during his 12 years in charge while taking a strong stand against doping, has died. He was 79.

title: The U.S. Is Off the E.U.s Safe List. What Does That Mean for Americans Traveling to Europe?
description: On Monday, the European Union removed the United States from its safe list of countries whose residents can travel to its 27 member states without requirements such as quarantine and testing. This generated confusion, with some people writing on social media that Americans have been banned from visiting Europe. Thats not actually what the recommendation means.

title: U.S. Military Announces End of Evacuation Effort in Afghanistan
description: Gen. Kenneth F. McKenzie Jr., the head of the U.S. Central Command, said that the United States had finished its withdrawal, ending the 20-year occupation of Afghanistan.

title: Virginia School Board to Pay $1.3 Million in Transgender Students Suit
description: A school board in Virginia has agreed to pay $1.3 million in legal fees to resolve a discrimination lawsuit filed by a former student whose efforts to use the boys bathroom put him at the center of a national debate over rights for transgender people.

title: Lee (Scratch) Perry, Bob Marley Mentor and Reggae Innovator, Dies at 85
description: Lee (Scratch) Perry, the innovative Jamaican producer who mentored Bob Marley and pushed reggae into the sonic avant-garde with his dub productions, died on Sunday in Lucea, Jamaica. He was 85.

title: For Benot Paire, Just Playing in the U.S. Open Felt Like Winning
description: A year ago, French tennis player Benot Paire spent the U.S. Open isolated in his Long Island hotel room after testing positive for Covid-19, unable to take his place in the draw and unable to find his happy place in the aftermath.

title: In Afghanistan, an Unceremonious End, and a Shrouded Beginning
description: The end of the United States longest war was unceremonious  trash blowing across the single airstrip of Kabuls international airport, Afghans lingering outside the gates, still hoping in vain for evacuation, Taliban firing victoriously into the night sky.

title: U.S. War in Afghanistan Ends as Final Evacuation Flights Depart
description: The last United States forces left Afghanistan late Monday, ending a 20-year occupation that began shortly after Al Qaedas attacks on 9/11, cost over $2 trillion, took more than 170,000 lives and ultimately failed to defeat the Taliban, the Islamist militants who allowed Al Qaeda to operate there.

title: In a final blow of the 20-year war, U.S. envoys close their embassy and exit Kabul.
description: WASHINGTON  American diplomats have left Afghanistan, and the U.S. Embassy in Kabul will remain closed, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Monday, after the military announced that it had completed its withdrawal from the country.

title: The Snake Oil Theory of the Modern Right
description: You dont hear much these days about economic anxiety. Most observers acknowledge that the rise of the Trumpist right was driven by racial and social antagonism, not economic populism.

title: On the Ground in Louisiana in Idas Wake
description: Widespread flooding and power outages continued across southeastern Louisiana on Tuesday as officials and emergency crews continued to assess the damage caused by Hurricane Ida, which struck the state on Sunday as a powerful Category 4 storm.

title: Florida withholds money from school districts over mask mandates.
description: The Florida Department of Education has withheld funds from two school districts that made masks mandatory in classrooms this fall, state officials announced on Monday, making good on a threat that local school boards that required students to wear masks would be punished financially.

title: We Have to Try: Lawmakers Rush to Assist in Afghanistan Evacuations.
description: WASHINGTON  Consumed with trying to help dozens of Afghans escape their country as U.S. troops prepared to withdraw, aides to Representative Michael Waltz, Republican of Florida, shifted their work schedules, coming in after midnight so they could talk evacuees through Taliban checkpoints.

title: Hurricane Veterans Were Stunned by Ida: Its Never Been as Bad
description: JEFFERSON PARISH, La.  Jordan Roque pulled his Chevy pickup truck onto the last stretch of highway outside of town that was not inundated by water on Monday, hauling an airboat. Hurricane Ida had turned the road into a makeshift boat launch, and Mr. Roque was on a mission to find his relatives.

title: In Louisiana, Rescue Workers Search for Those Stranded by Hurricane Ida
description: NEW ORLEANS  Rescue teams fanned out across Louisiana on Monday searching for people left stranded in the aftermath of Hurricane Ida, even as New Orleans emerged from its most serious onslaught since Hurricane Katrina confident that its levees had held.

title: Charges in Bali Bombing Case Are Delayed at Guantnamo
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba  Translation and interpretation problems on Monday delayed by one day military efforts to formally charge three Southeast Asian men  held by the United States for 18 years  with conspiring in deadly terrorist bombings in Indonesia in 2002 and 2003.

title: The Intolerable Wait for a Kids Vaccine
description: Julie Swann, an engineer who studies health systems and models infectious disease at North Carolina State University, leads a team of researchers who recently tried to simulate how the Delta variant of the coronavirus could move through schools in various scenarios. The results, which The Washington Post published over the weekend, were alarming.

title: Fans waited an extra year for the U.S. Open. Then they waited some more.
description: As the first tennis balls were struck in earnest at the U.S. Open on Monday, thousands of frustrated tennis fans waited patiently to get inside for the first time in two years, stuck in a human traffic jam that left many feeling angry and sick in the hot sun.

title: Transcript of Blinkens Speech on New Chapter in Afghanistan
description: The following is a transcript of Secretary of State Antony J. Blinkens remarks on Monday about the U.S. plan for engagement with Afghanistan after evacuations ended and the last American troops departed.

title: Blinken: A Diplomatic Mission Has Begun in Afghanistan
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said fewer than 200 Americans were still in Afghanistan, pledging safe passage for them and assistance for Afghans who were at risk of reprisal for working with the U.S. government.

title: Federal Judge Strikes Down Trump Rule Governing Water Pollution
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge on Monday struck down a Trump-era environmental rule that drastically limited federal restrictions against pollution of millions of streams, wetlands and marshes across the country.

title: Iowa Farmworker Gets Life in Prison for the Murder of Mollie Tibbetts
description: A farmworker was sentenced on Monday to life in prison without the possibility of parole in the fatal stabbing of an Iowa college student in 2018, a crime that Donald J. Trump seized upon as president as he amplified his hard-line policies against illegal immigration.

title: A Cut Above
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  Congratulations to Eric Bornstein, who is making his fifth appearance in the New York Times Crossword this year alone, and his seventh altogether in just over a year. Now that is a cut above!

title: Naomi Osaka, happy to play for a crowd, wins her first-round match.
description: Naomi Osaka had a solid start to the defense of her U.S. Open title, posting a 6-4, 6-1 win over Marie Bouzkova of the Czech Republic that was a little closer than the final score suggested.

title: 2021 U.S. Open: What to Watch on Tuesday
description: How to watch: From noon to 6 p.m. Eastern on ESPN; 7 to 11 p.m. on ESPN2; and streaming on the ESPN app.

title: For These Paralympians, a Pursuit of Excellence Means Life Abroad
description: TOKYO  To play wheelchair basketball for a living, members of the U.S. Paralympic mens team have put their passports through vigorous workouts.

title: Quotation of the Day: How the Delta Variant Spread From a Teacher to Half of Her Students
description: If teacher has no mask, move to the back of the class.

title: Corrections: Aug. 31, 2021
description: An article on Sunday about U.S. veterans who are acting as digital guides to Americans and Afghans trying to flee Afghanistan misidentified a project manager from North Carolina who had served in the Marines. He is Rich Porter, not Phil.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: The last U.S. forces left Afghanistan late last night, ending a 20-year occupation that began shortly after Sept. 11, cost over $2 trillion, took more than 170,000 lives and ultimately failed to defeat the Taliban, the Islamist militants who allowed Al Qaeda to operate there.

title: Inside Kabul airport, the last American soldier leaves, and the first Taliban fighters arrive.
description: The last moments of the U.S. occupation of Afghanistan were captured in two images that were a reversal of the American invasion nearly 20 years ago: A U.S. soldier leaving as Taliban fighters took control.

title: Searching for Bird Life in a Former Ocean of Forest
description: FLORENCIA, Colombia  In June 1912, Leo Miller, a collector with the American Museum of Natural History, arrived in the Caqueta region of Colombia, where the eastern foothills of the Andes melt into the forested lowlands of the Amazon basin.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: TUESDAY  Hi busy bees! Welcome to todays Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: Hurricane Ida could make the supply chain disaster even worse.
description: In normal times, the devastation of a massive hurricane like Ida tends to be followed by an aggressive rebuilding effort, as carpenters, roofers and other skilled workers descend on affected communities to repair the damage.

title: Jury selection for the Elizabeth Holmes trial has begun.
description: Jury selection began on Tuesday in the long-awaited trial of Elizabeth Holmes, the disgraced founder of the blood testing start-up Theranos, who faces a dozen counts of fraud and conspiracy to commit wire fraud.

title: The Stenographer Who Married Dostoyevsky  and Saved Him From Ruin
description: THE GAMBLER WIFEA True Story of Love, Risk, and the Woman Who Saved Dostoyevsky By Andrew D. Kaufman

title: How to Solve Any Problem Using Just Common Sense
description: Whenever I got stuck on math homework while growing up, I would go looking for my mother. Often I would find her on the living-room couch unwinding after work, catching up on the news with both the local Cantonese news station blaring on the TV and The Economist open in her lap.

title: My Reading Habits, Explained, and Other Questions You Asked
description: We asked for your questions, and you answered. Hundreds and hundreds of fantastic questions poured in, and our producer Annie Galvin joined me to ask some of the best of them. Does the infrastructure bill mean theres more hope for bipartisanship than we thought? Whats my view on the degrowth movement? What do I think my book, Why Were Polarized, got right, and what did it get wrong? Will plant- and cell-based meats ever be cheaper than eating animals, given the subsidies the meat industry gets? Why hasnt any blue state created a single-payer health care system? Can you really build more housing without creating a biodiversity crisis?

title: My Stepdad Has Alzheimers. Can My Mom Date Someone Else?
description: What are your thoughts on the spouse of an early-onset Alzheimers patient dating while said patient is still alive? By way of background, my mother was the full-time caregiver of my stepfather until a few months ago, when he was moved to assisted living, and she is lonely and missing companionship. The man my mother has chosen to date is in his mid-70s (seven years older than my mother), has lost all his money, has three failed marriages and generally has a poor reputation. The way the news was broken to us children (two stepchildren, including me, and two biological children) could have been better, and we are worried our mother is acting out of fear of being alone.

title: How to Collect Crystals
description: If youre looking for crystals, Arkansas is the best in the world, says Bryan Major, 43, a self-described rock hound from Wilmington, N.C., who spends much of the year traveling the country digging for minerals, gems and crystals. His YouTube videos documenting his outings have been viewed more than 57 million times.

title: Joe Bidens Critics Lost Afghanistan
description: A month ago I thought I was a cynic about our 20-year war in Afghanistan. Today, after watching our stumbling withdrawal and the swift collapse of practically everything we fought for, my main feeling is that I wasnt cynical enough.

title: Can Magnesium Supplements Really Help You Sleep?
description: Magnesium is often touted as an antidote to poor sleep. But while some doctors say it is fine to take it in supplemental form for certain sleep disruptions, like those caused by restless legs syndrome, the evidence for its sleep-inducing benefits is thin.

title: Do Republicans Actually Want the Pandemic to End?
description: President Barack Obama promised unity. In his 2008 campaign, he said he would heal the nations political divides and end more than a decade of partisan rancor.

title: In the Kitchens of the Rich, Things Are Not as They Seem
description: The kitchens of the wealthy in the United States today are capable of providing a humbling experience to the uninitiated. Attempts to procure ice cubes can transform the most dignified guest into a hapless burglar rummaging through drawers for loose gems.

title: A Dedicated Horsewoman Leaves No Thoroughbred Behind
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  Jessica Paquette calls herself a weird horse girl. She was 6 when she was first entranced by them, at a New England fair. They were so big, but gentle enough for her to reach up and rub their noses.

title: The Winners of Remote Work
description: Who wins and who loses when companies can hire from anywhere?

title: Worrying About Your Carbon Footprint Is Exactly What Big Oil Wants You to Do
description: Everybodys going carbon neutral these days, from the big boys  Amazon, Microsoft, Unilever, Starbucks, JetBlue  to your favorite outdoor brand, even ski resorts. Probably your neighborhood coffee roaster, too.

title: Hurricane Ida Offers a Glimpse of the Dystopia Thats Coming for All of Us
description: As a boy, Louis Armstrong worked for the Karnofsky family. The Karnofskys tailor shop on South Rampart Street in New Orleans became a second home to him, and the family helped him buy his first cornet. On Sunday night, the Karnofsky building, long neglected by the city and a succession of private owners who promised to restore it, finally collapsed under the force of Hurricane Idas winds.

title: A Sadness I Cant Carry: The Story Of The Drum

After the first battles at Lexington and Concord in 1775, the colonies took about eight years to beat the British and create a new nation.

title: Three Rooms, by Jo Hamya: An Excerpt
description: Sink and unframed mirror. The southwest corner of the room. My phone, propped up between the faucet and the wall, and my lips in the mirror, and my fingers doing their little tap, tap over them with a tissue, blotting lipstick. All to the sound of my mother: Do we think that dress is the right choice for a work party, and my mother, Did you make sure they got the inventory form, and my mother, Are you making friends, and my mother, I miss you, when will you come home? The soft little worries running alongside the tap. I let them go down the plughole. It wasnt enough. Some aspect of them stayed, as though theyd filtered from the faucet into the glass of water Id had before leaving for the meet and greet. I got lost on the way to the English faculty and ended up late.

title: HOWM Cocina & Cocktails Opens in Chelsea
description: The name is pronounced home. Remembering how its spelled is something else. The idea, according to the Gilded Group, which manages the restaurant in partnership with the Selina Chelsea hotel, is to express people coming together with food and drink. Got that? What the name doesnt reflect is the nature of the food and drink, a focused exploration of Mexico, Central America and South America. (The hotel is part of a chain with a strong presence in Central America and Mexico.) The chef, Byron Peafiel, a native of Ecuador, takes some liberties with tradition: His small plates include pupusas with curtido (a kind of cabbage slaw), charred octopus with jalapeo hummus, and grilled broccolini in a mole sauce. Large dishes are guava-glazed roasted chicken, aged churrasco (rib-eye for two) with chimichurri, and chaulafan (Ecuadorean fried rice) chicharrone using black rice, seafood, pork rinds and salsa verde. Deep-fried plantains (patacones) are served for the table, complimentary. Gilded Groups beverage director, Daniel Bedoya, who was raised in Ecuador, has devised an array of cocktails. These are served in the airy ground-floor restaurant with yellow accents that has outdoor terrace seating on two levels, and also at the 10th-floor Rooftop at Selina Chelsea with expansive views and a plunge pool. (Opens Wednesday)
